thread.title: Windows 10 problem solvers: My must-have utilities (and many are free)
thread.title_full: Windows 10 problem solvers: My must-have utilities (and many are free)

title: Windows 10 problem solvers: My must-have utilities (and many are free)
text:
ZDNet Japan Overcome annoyances and solve problems 
Windows 10 comes with plenty of awesome built-in apps, but sometimes... I want more. When I need to support multiple keyboards, modify images in bulk, customize my keyboard, uninstall stubborn apps, uncompress pretty much everything, or play nearly every media format -- there's a tool in this collection that will come to my rescue. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: ZDNet 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Share a mouse and keyboard across computers 
If you have more than one machine on your desk, you know it's a pain to have multiple keyboards and mice. Synergy is a virtual KVM that works across PCs, Macs, and Linux boxes. It's $19, but worth it. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: Symless 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Turn your tablet into an external monitor 
It's well known that more screen real estate increases productivity. Given we all have tablets lying around, why not use them as an extra screen for your laptop? That's what Spacedesk is does for you, for free. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: datronicsoft 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Automatically modify images in bulk 
If have any kind of bulk image converting tasks, Reaconverter is the tool to use. You can create simple scripts and droplets that will transform entire folders nearly instantly. There's a free version. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: Reasoft 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Customize keyboard behavior at the nano-level 
KeyTweak looks old because it's been around for a long time. But it still works and it's free. If you need to surgically alter your keyboard, this is the tool for you. Not for newbies. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: Softonic 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Eliminate excess software 
It's hard to believe, but PCs still come loaded with crap. PC Decrapifier has been with us for years and is still a go-to tool to clean the crap from your machine. It's a free download. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: PC Decrapifier 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Display image thumbnails instead of generic icons 
The Windows desktop and File Explorer show thumbnails for some file formats, but not all. If you want to see (and customize) thumbnails for many more formats, MysticThumbs is your friend. $30. Just one snag: it has a problem displaying thumbnails from shares. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: MysticCoder 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Uninstall stubborn apps 
At almost $40, this isn't cheap. But if you want to cleanly remove applications from your Windows install, Revo Uninstaller Pro can save you a lot of time, and even save you from having to do a fresh install... for a while. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: VS Revo Group 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Switch to the right network 
For those who remember NetProfileSwitch, Mobile Net Switch is a tool that's been updated for Windows 10. As you move from network to network, it adjusts your PC's network configuration automatically. About $30. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: RH Computing 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Find out what's in your computer 
If you've ever needed to know your machine's configuration (say, to find the right drivers), Speccy is the go-to product. There's a free version that should do for most needs. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: Piriform 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Find keys for installed products 
If you want to reinstall your system, it's often necessary to re-register with the appropriate product key. If you can't find your original order, the $30 Recover Keys can help. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: One Up LTD 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Find what's clogging your storage 
Why is my drive suddenly full? Ever have that happen to you? With WinDirStat , you can see all your files at a glance and easily see the clusters of files that are taking up way too much space. Oh, yeah. It's totally free. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: Wikipedia 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Avoid driving 3 hours to fix Mom's computer 
Back in the day, there was Windows Remote Assistant. Today, Windows 10 supports Quick Assist , which will help you fix machines remotely. If both of you don't run Windows 10, consider TeamViewer -- there's a free version. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: Microsoft 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Uncompress pretty much everything 
So someone just sent you a file compressed with some odd format. Consider 7-Zip your go-to tool. It can uncompress 7z, XZ, BZIP2, GZIP, TAR, ZIP, WIM, AR, ARJ, CAB, CHM, CPIO, CramFS, DMG, EXT, FAT, GPT, HFS, IHEX, ISO, LZH, LZMA, MBR, MSI, NSIS, NTFS, QCOW2, RAR, RPM, SquashFS, UDF, UEFI, VDI, VHD, VMDK, WIM, XAR and Z files. 
Price: Free. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: 7-Zip 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Play nearly every media format 
Affectionately known as "the cone," VLC will play nearly any media format you can think of (and many you can't). Plus, it's free. You can't beat that! Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: VideoLAN 
Caption by: David Gewirtz Batch rename files with custom rules 
I can't tell you how many times ReNamer has come in handy. It has complex rules, so you can batch rename files and customize them at the same time. It's been around for a long time, there's a pro version, but the free version should meet most needs. Published: February 23, 2017 -- 13:39 GMT (13:39 GMT) 
Photo by: Denis Kozlov
